t: Then Jonathan sent his brother as captain over the host, that he might entreat his friends the Nabataeans, that they might leave with them his carriage, which was much.
But the sons of Ambri came forth out of Medaba, and took John, and all that he had, and went their way withal.

After this came tidings to Jonathan and Simon his brother, that the children of Ambri did celebrate a great marriage, and were bringing the bride from Nabatha with a great train, as being the daughter of one of the great men of Canaan.
Therefore they remembered John their brother, and went up, and hid themselves under the covert of the mountain:

And they lifted up their eyes, and looked, and, behold, there was much ado and a great carriage: and the bridegroom came forth, and his friends and brethren, with timbrels, and pipes, and many instruments of musick.
Then Jonathan rose up against them from the place where they lay in ambush, and made a slaughter of them in such sort, as many fell down dead, and the remnant fled into the mountain,
And Jonathan took all the spoils.
Thus was the marriage turned into mourning, and the noise of their melody into lamentation.
So when they had fully avenged the blood of their brother, they turned again to the marsh of Jordan.
Now when Bacchides heard hereof, he came on the sabbath day unto the banks of Jordan with a great power.
Then Jonathan said to his company, Up! let us fight for our lives: for it standeth not with us to day, as in time past:
For, behold, the battle is before us and behind us, and the water of Jordan on this side and on that side, the marsh likewise and thickets: and there is no place whither to turn ourselves.
Now therefore cry ye unto heaven, that ye may be delivered from the hand of your enemies.
And Jonathan began to strike, and he lifted up his hand to smite Bacchides, but he swerved back from him.
Then Jonathan, with them that were with him, leaped into Jordan, and swam over unto that other bank: howbeit Bacchides went not over Jordan unto them.
So there were slain of Bacchides' side that day about a thousand men.

Afterward returned Bacchides to Jerusalem, and repaired the strong cities in Judaea; to wit, Jericho, and Emmaus, and Bethoron, and Bethel, and Thamnatha, Pharathoni, and Taphon, with high walls, and gates, and bars.
And in them he set garrisons, that they might vex Israel.
He fortified also the city Bethsura, and Gazara, and the tower, and put forces in them, and provision of victuals.
Beside, he took the chief men's sons in the country for hostages, and put them into the tower at Jerusalem.

Now in the hundred and fifty and third year, in the second month, Alcimus commanded to pull down the wall of the inner court of the sanctuary, thereby to destroy the works of the prophets; but his purpose was not fully brought to pass.
For after this Alcimus was plagued, and his enterprises were hindered: for his mouth was stopped, that he could not speak, neither give order concerning his house.
So Alcimus died at that time with great torment.
Now when Bacchides saw that Alcimus was dead, he returned to the king: then the land of Judea was in rest two years.

Whereupon all the wicked men took counsel, saying, Behold, Jonathan and his company are at ease, and dwell without care: now therefore we will bring Bacchides hither, who shall take them all in one night.
So they went and consulted with him.

Then removed Bacchides, and came with a great host, and sent letters privily to his adherents in Judea, that they should take Jonathan and those that were with him: but they could not, because their counsel was known unto them.
Wherefore they took of the men of the country, that were authors of that mischief, about fifty persons, and slew them.
Afterward Jonathan, and Simon, and they that were with him, gat them away unto Bethbasi, which is in the wilderness, and they repaired the decayes thereof, and made it strong.
When Bacchides heard thereof, he gathered together all his host, and sent word to them that were of Judea.
Then came he and laid siege against Bethbasi; and for a long season he battered it, and made engines of war.
But Jonathan left his brother Simon in the city, and went forth himself into the country, and with a certain number went he forth.
And he smote Odomera and his brethren, and the children of Phasiron in their tent.
And Simon and his company went forth out of the city, and burned up the engines of war,
And fought against Bacchides, who was discomfited by them, and they vexed him sore: for his counsel and travail was in vain.
Wherefore he was very wroth with the wicked men that gave him counsel to come into the country, insomuch as he slew many of them, and purposed to return into his own land.
Whereof when Jonathan had knowledge, he sent ambassadors unto him, to the end that he should make peace with him, and deliver them the prisoners.
Which thing he accepted, and did according to his appointments, and sware that he would never do him harm all the days of his life.
When therefore he had restored unto him the prisoners that he had taken aforetime out of the land of Judea, he returned into his own land, neither came he thenceforth any more into their borders.
Thus the sword ceased from Israel: but Jonathan dwelt at Machmas, and began to govern the people; and he destroyed the ungodly men out of Israel.
In the hundred and sixtieth year Alexander, the son of Antiochus Epiphanes, went up and took Ptolemais: for the people had received him, by means whereof he reigned there.
Now when king Demetrius heard thereof, he gathered together an exceeding great host, and went forth against him to fight.
Moreover Demetrius sent letters unto Jonathan with loving words, unto the end he might honour him.
For said he, Let us first make a league with him, before Alexander join with him against us:
Else he will remember all the evils that we did against him, and against his brethren, and against his nation.

Wherefore he gave him authority to gather together an host, and to provide weapons, that he might aid him in battle: he commanded also that the hostages that were in the tower should be delivered him.
Then came Jonathan to Jerusalem, and read the letters in the audience of all the people, and of them that were in the tower:
Who were sore afraid, when they heard that the king had given him authority to gather together an host.
Whereupon they of the tower delivered their hostages unto Jonathan, and he delivered them unto their parents.
This done, Jonathan settled himself to dwell at Jerusalem, and began to build and repair the city.
And he commanded the workmen to build the walls and the mount Sion round about with square stones, for fortification; and they did so.
Then the strangers, that were in the fortresses which Bacchides had built, fled away;
Insomuch as every man left his place, and went into his own country.
Only at Bethsura certain of those that had forsaken the law and the commandments remained behind; for it was a place of refuge.
Now when king Alexander had heard what promises Demetrius had sent unto Jonathan: when also he heard of the battles and noble acts which he had done, and of the pains that he had endured,
He said, Shall we find such another man? now therefore we will make him our friend and confederate.
So he wrote a letter unto him in this manner, saying,
King Alexander unto his brother Jonathan sendeth greeting:
We have heard of thee, that thou art a man of great power, and meet to be our friend:

Wherefore now we do ordain thee this day to be the high priest of thy nation, and to be called the king's friend; (and therewithal he sent unto him a purple robe and a crown of gold:) and require thee to take our part, and keep friendship with us.
So in the seventh month of the hundred and sixtieth year, at the feast of the tabernacles, Jonathan put on the holy robe, and gathered together forces, and provided much armour.
Whereof when Demetrius heard, he was right sorry, and said,
What have we done, that Alexander hath prevented us in getting the friendship of the Jews to strengthen himself?
I will write unto them also words of encouragement, and promise them dignities and gifts, that I may have their aid.
He sent unto them therefore to this effect: King Demetrius unto the people of the Jews sendeth greeting:
Whereas ye have kept covenants with us, and continued in our friendship, not joining yourselves with our enemies, we have heard hereof, and are glad.
Now therefore continue ye still to be faithful unto us, and we will well recompense you for the things ye do in our behalf,
And will grant you many immunities, and give you rewards.
And now do I free you from all tributes, and release you from the customs of salt, and from crown taxes,

And from that which should have been levied for my use of the fruits of the earth, and of the trees, that happeneth to be mine to receive, from henceforth I release them of it: so that they shall not be taken of the land of Judea, nor of the three governments which are added thereunto out of the country of Samaria and Galilee, from this day forth for evermore.
Let Jerusalem also be holy and free, with the borders thereof; both from tenths and tributes.
And as for the tower which is at Jerusalem, I yield up my authority over it, and give it to the high priest, that he may set in it such men as he shall choose to keep it.

Moreover, I freely set at liberty every one of the Jews, that have been carried captives out of the land of Judea into any part of my kingdom, and I will that all my officers pay no taxes even upon their cattle.

Furthermore, I ordain that the temple be maintained, even out of the king's accounts, and that all the holy vessels that ye have made be restored: yea, also, that the things that ye have built and repaired be maintained at my cost.
Yea, moreover, I give you five and twenty thousand shekels of silver yearly, out of the revenues of the country, for the service of the temple.
And that which remaineth, which the officers did not pay in time past, from henceforth shall be paid toward the works of the temple.

And beside this, I release the three portions of the country of Judea, that are annexed unto Samaria, of the tribute, that they may be joined with Judea, and be reckoned to be under one, nor bound to obey other authority than the high priest's.
As for Ptolemais also, and the land pertaining thereto, I give it unto the sanctuary at Jerusalem, for the expenses that belong to the sanctuary.
Moreover, I give every year fifteen thousand shekels of silver out of mine own revenues, which they take from convenient places.
Therefore all the money that the officers have not reckoned, as in former years, from henceforth shall they give it toward the works of the temple.
Moreover the five thousand shekels of silver, which were taken from the sanctuary profits each year, even this shall be released, as it belongeth to the priests that minister in the service.

Whosoever shall flee unto the Temple in Jerusalem, and within all the borders thereof, being indebted for royal taxes, or for any other matter, let them be quit, with all that they have within my kingdom.
For the work also of the building and repairing of the sanctuary, the expense shall be given of the king's accounts.
For the building also of the walls of Jerusalem, and the fortifying thereof round about, the expense shall be given of the king's account, as also for the building of the walls in Judea.

Now when Jonathan and the people heard these words, they gave no credit unto them, nor received them, because they remembered the great evil that Demetrius did in Israel, and how greatly he had afflicted them.
Wherefore they took their pleasure in Alexander, because he had moved them thereto, and they clave unto him.
Then King Alexander gathered great forces, and camped over against Demetrius.
And the two kings joined battle, and Demetrius' host fled: but Alexander followed after him, and prevailed against them.
And he increased in power, and fought valiantly until the sun went down: and that day was Demetrius slain.
Afterward Alexander sent ambassadors unto Ptolemee king of Egypt with words to this effect:
"Forasmuch as I am come again to my kingdom, and am set in the throne of my progenitors, and have gotten the dominion, and have overthrown Demetrius, and recovered our country,
Yea, I joined battle with him, and have overthrown him and his host: wherefore now will I return unto his kingdom,
Now therefore let us make a league of amity together, and I will give thee my daughter to wife: and I will endow her with gifts, as are worthy of thee.
Then Ptolemee answered again, saying, "Blessed be the day wherein thou didst return unto the land of thy fathers, and sattest in the throne of their kingdom:
Now therefore will I do unto thee, as thou hast written: meet me therefore at Ptolemais, that we may see one another; for I will marry my daughter to thee according to thy desire.
So Ptolemee went out of Egypt with his daughter Cleopatra, unto Ptolemais in the hundred and threescore and second year:
Where King Alexander meeting him, he gave him his daughter Cleopatra, and celebrated her marriage at Ptolemais with great glory, as the manner of kings is.
Then King Alexander wrote unto Jonathan, that he should come and meet him.
Who thereupon went to Ptolemais, where he met the two kings, and gave them and their friends silver, and gold, and many presents, and found favour in their sight.
At that time certain pestilent fellows, children of Belial, gathered themselves together against him, to accuse him: but the king would not hear them:
